name: Subscribe (the best deal for you and for us)
description:
Do away with remembering and have GDS delivered straight to you. Perfect for agoraphobics and Salman Rushdie. Also a great gift if anyone you know is agoraphobic or Salman Rushdie. Our all-new subscriber deals give you the best possible savings while giving us the stability to plan for the future. And there's not much better than a new, beautifully made book arriving in the mail. Going Down Swinging currently produces one major print and audio CD anthology per year, along with periodic digital editions, ongoing website content, and a wide range of events. Your subscription is measured in print editions, but also gives you access to our entire program, while subscribers who can't attend events can choose a discount subscription. For instance, a four-issue subscription will give you:
  • Four impeccably designed print editions
  • Four copies of our annual audio anthology
  • All digital editions released in the subscription period
  • All postage included, no hidden costs
  • Confirmation of your postal address each issue
  • First look at each new edition
  • Access to any locked web content
  • Golden Ticket subscribers get free entry to all GDS events in the subscription period. (That could be four years' worth of nights out)
  • Renewing subscribers get a ten percent refund
When you subscribe, we'll email you to find out which issue you'd like to begin with. This is by far the cheapest way you can get this many GDS publications and attend this many events, and it makes an excellent and lasting present for people you like. After four years they'll still know you like them. Postage is included in all domestic AND international prices. ___________________________________________________ To help us avoid fees, the best payment method is direct deposit to our bank account. Get your purchase total from the checkout page, then deposit that amount in our account via netbank or a branch deposit. Include the word 'Order' along with your last name, then email us and let us know what you wanted. Going Down Swinging BSB: 704-191 Account: 67038 info@goingdownswinging.org.au If you'd rather use a credit card, simply continue with your checkout process using PayPal.

name: Going Down Swinging #35
description:
The 35th issue of Going Down Swinging is here!

A chockers print and audio anthology that will take you to the wrong parts of Baltimore, drag you along the Silk Road, breathe cured meats at you in suburban Adelaide then break your heart on a Californian highway. You’ll meet Pavlichenko, the most successful female sniper in history; a Japanese whaler losing himself at sea; a guy struggling with psychedelics at a funeral; and real people who believe they’re mythical creatures trapped in human bodies.

All this is threaded together by our commissioned artist Darren Song, who produces intricate embroidery work on paper. For this project Darren chose eight spreads from vintage editions of Going Down Swinging and embroidered them with his response to the writing in No. 35. The results are beautiful and surprising.

The accompanying audio album features new stories and spoken word from the likes of Anis Mojgani, Angie Hart, Benezra, Adam Gibson, and The Herd's rhythm section playing as Bass Elefant. You can get the album as a digital download, or a stamped CD with a risograph poster case.

The edition comes with a radical new look and feel courtesy of design studio Holiday.

name: Going Down Swinging #34 Digital
description: Going Down Swinging No. 34 is a multimedia literary journal interweaving narratives in words, pictures, sound, and motion. Available as a tablet app or a desktop download, No. 34 has the work we can't possibly put in print, with interactive comics from Mike Baylis, fiction for the eye and ear from Laura Jean McKay, and historical mystery solving from Lachlan Plain (with a special guest appearance from Michael Cathcart), all bundled in a stunning and innovative digital design by Vanessa Hughes. Should I buy the App or the Online version? No.34 comes in two flavours - an iOS App for iPads and iPhones, and the Online version for all other platforms. The Online version works on desktop computers and mobile devices, including phones and tablets (Android and Apple). All you need is an internet connection and the right browser (see below). The Online version is available now from this page. The App version will be available from the Apple App Store in a few more days, by searching for No.34. You can have both, if you like - you only pay for the edition once. If you have bought the App and want access to the online version, simply email us and we'll provide access details. If you have bought the online version and subsequently want the App, purchase the App through the App Store, then email us to refund your first transaction. Can I view this book? No.34 uses HTML5 and CSS3 liberally as well as some other ingredients. Internet browsers don't always play ball with websites, so we strongly recommend you use either Chrome (PCs and Macs) or Safari (Macs) to view it. If you are using Firefox you will also need Adobe Flash installed. We don't recommend you view the book in Internet Explorer. All this software is free. If you are using this software, but the book isn't displaying properly, it's possible your browser is old and needs to be updated, or that your operating system (such as Windows or OS X) is out of date. Again, we strongly recommend you update your operating systems to be sure to experience the book at its best. How long after I buy it until I can read it? Digital delivery is much faster than the post, however it may take up to one working day for you to receive your secure login to the online version. Login information and instructions will be emailed to whatever email address you use to buy the book - so make sure it's correct. App customers can view as soon as you purchase and download. ___________________________________________________ To help us avoid fees, the best payment method is direct deposit to our bank account. Get your purchase total from the checkout page, then deposit that amount in our account via netbank or a branch deposit. Include the word 'Order' along with your last name, then email us and let us know what you wanted. Going Down Swinging BSB: 704-191 Account: 67038 info@goingdownswinging.org.au If you'd rather use a credit card, simply continue with your checkout process using PayPal.

name: Going Down Swinging #33
description:
Featuring • A commissioned centrepiece collaboration between author Cate Kennedy and artist Simon MacEwan, presented over 16 pages in vibrant full colour. • Long-form commissioned spoken word pieces by playwright and actor Felix Nobis, and acclaimed rapper Mantra. • Our one-off Jesus Section, so named for issue #33, featuring nine perspectives on JC from satire to tribute to analysis. • Brand-new recording from breakthrough soul duo Sietta, covering Tom Waits’ theme song from The Wire in line with our Jesus theme. • Briohny Doyle’s commissioned essay ‘Little Monsters’, an incisively humorous and human look at Alien and Prometheus, motherhood, and our conception of the monstrous birth. • 15-track CD including The Bedroom Philosopher, Joe Dolce, blues singer Anita George, legendary poet PiO, and Sean M. Whelan’s collaboration with The Mime Set. • Bold new design from Santangelo + Hall, featuring a pantone text layout; reverse-printed pull-quotes making use of paper show-through; visual features adapted from a 1961 World Atlas; carefully selected stocks; Biblical scans; a CD case incorporated into a special fold; and a die-cut cover contrasting the book’s pantone with the full-colour CD sleeve. • Going Down Swinging’s 1000th contributor, including work this issue from the USA, Russia, India, Spain, and all around Australia. • All of this collated into a 272-page book featuring the freshest new fiction, essay, visual art and poetry, with an accompanying CD of music, storytelling and spoken word. At GDS, entertainment is as important as drama and insight.

As an online deal, we'll roll postage into the cost for Australian orders.

name: Going Down Swinging #32
description:
Featuring Neil Gaiman, Joelistics, Leanne Hall, Dylan Martorell, Pat Grant, Rebecca Giggs, Alex Skovron, Ruby Murray, Eleanor Jackson, Benezra, Fiona Wright, Anthony O'Sullivan, Sean M. Whelan, Briohny Doyle, Graham Nunn... so many more...

Edited by Geoff Lemon and Jessica Friedmann, GDS #32 is one of the most ambitious editions we've ever put together.

  • Full print anthology with a form-cut, hand-lettered cover, containing 37 stories, drawings, comics, and poems, from the US, Bulgaria, Lithuania, New Zealand, and all around Australia, in a book pretty enough to leave on the coffee table.
  • 14-track CD printed with original artwork, featuring storytellers and spoken word from the world over.
  • Celestial Taxi, our commissioned writer/illustrator collaboration between in-demand novelist Leanne Hall and design superstar Dylan Martorell, presented as a full-colour flipbook insert that folds out into a poster.
  • GDS spoken word commissions from Eleanor Jackson, Ezra Bix, and Maxine Clarke.
  • Our first-ever non-fiction commission from Rebecca Giggs.

As an online deal, we'll roll postage into the cost.

name: Going Down Swinging #31 Digital
description:
Technical requirements: The discrete .epub version of GDS #31 is designed to be read/viewed as an e-book via iPads and iPhones. It's best viewed via the free iBooks app - just drop the book into your iTunes library, sync, and go.

For desktop/laptop users and Android users, we currently offer a web version of the anthology to be viewed in your browser.

___________________________

Australian literature's first fully interactive multimedia journal edition, and Going Down Swinging's first foray into digital publishing, this is also the first offering from the editorial duo of Jessica Friedmann and Geoff Lemon.

GDS #31 goes way beyond the standard concept of the e-book, with a fully integrated multimedia publication: a stunning mix of film, animation, spoken word, illustration, photography, poetry, fiction and essay. 

Purchases will receive passwords and download instructions by email. These may change periodically, so if you have any trouble, email info@goingdownswinging.org.au

Note: To help us avoid fees, the best payment method is via direct deposit to our bank account. Put your purchases in your cart, then go to the checkout page. Deposit the listed amount in our bank account, using your own netbanking site or a branch deposit. Include the word 'Order' along with your last name (or as much as will fit) in the description box. Then email info@goingdownswinging.org.au and let us know the items you ordered, their individual prices, and the total.

name: Going Down Swinging #30
description:
The bumper double issue to celebrate GDS’s 30th birthday – 1980 to 2010 – this is a huge 172-page edition, with a double-CD spoken word anthology (one Australian, one international), a lavish full-colour graphic novella, and the most beautiful cover in GDS history.

Founders Kevin Brophy and Myron Lysenko are joined by past editors Grant Caldwell and Adam Ford in selecting new works of short fiction, poetry, comic art, haiku and haiga for this commemorative edition of Going Down Swinging.

The two accompanying spoken word CDs include both new local works as well as international selections from guest editors Christin O’Keefe Aptowicz (USA), Ian Ferrier (Canada), David Prater (Europe) and Ian Daley (UK), featuring some of the very best spoken word and slam poetry artists working today.

Through the support of Arts Victoria, GDS has also commissioned for this issue a new short story by Paddy O’Reilly, a longform poem by Eddie Paterson, and a full-colour graphic novella by Michael Camilleri.

Published 2010

name: Going Down Swinging Deluxe Box Set
description:
Want to find a present for your cleverest friend? Want to talk about back in the day, before Bryce Courtenay sold out and went mainstream, man? The answer is the GDS Box Set. Twelve issues covering over a decade of the life of Australia's most diverse literary journal.

We start with the very first spoken word CD issue, through the comic art specials, the spoken-word-only double CD, the street art issue, to the beautiful large-format editions of the Lanson-Greenaway years, ending with GDS #29 from December 2009. 

The box, admittedly, is limited to the cardboard one they'll arrive in, but it's the set that really counts.

And the best part? At this price, it comes in at just $8.25 per issue plus postage.

(Issues before #18 are scarce, and some are unavailable, but we may be able to help - enquire direct at info@goingdownswinging.org.au)

name: Going Down Swinging #29
description:
Editors: Lisa Greenaway, Klare Lanson

The stand-out feature of #29 was the spoken word collaboration with Overload Poetry Festival. GDS sent audio teams to all of Overload’s shows in 2009, committing them to the electronic record, and selecting the best offerings to feature on the GDS #29 CD.

The result is an extraordinary range of work from local and visiting performers. There’s live material from The Bedroom Philosopher’s Songs from the 86 Tram; the entirely spellbinding closing monologue from American jazz poet L. E. Scott; heartaching rural snapshots from Cate Kennedy; an extract from Nathan Curnow’s Ghost Poetry Project; award-winning indigenous writer Ali Cobby Eckermann’s tales of family; Anthony O’Sullivan’s ebullient Nirvana tribute written for Liner Notes; and a future GDS commission writer in Felix Nobis seeing a storm coming in.

The book contains the wonderful graphic novella ‘Where the Wild Things Aren’t’, by Oslo Davis, along with work from Chris Flynn, Simon Cox, Josephine Rowe, and New York writer Cristin O’Keefe Aptowicz.

Published 2009

name: Going Down Swinging #28
description:
Editors: Lisa Greenaway, Klare Lanson 

Again teaming up Greenaway and Lanson as editors, #28 featured one of the more distinctive GDS covers, with a pastel blue fantasia of characters spilling across the book. 

It included writing all-rounder Paul Mitchell, graphic artist Vanessa Hutchinson, Penguin Plays Rough founder Pip Smith, and the multi-award-winning Jillian Pattinson.

GDS’s spoken word commission series really began to hit its stride, with the full work from the three-part stage show Static included on this CD. Nathan Curnow, Alicia Sometimes, and Sean M. Whelan were the three writers, collaborating with musician Quinn Stacpoole. Static had previously toured for performances around Victoria, including at the BMW Edge Theatre for the Melbourne Writers Festival.

Published 2009

name: Going Down Swinging #27
description:
Editors: Lisa Greenaway, Klare Lanson 

#27 saw the arrival of editor Klare Lanson to partner Lisa Greenaway, with Steve Grimwade signing off after a mammoth nine issues at the helm. The format of Grimwade’s final issue was retained, as the characteristics of Greenaway’s curatorship began to gain prominence.

This issue’s text offerings included George Dunford, Australian poetry slam winner Kelly-Lee Hickey, and the New York’s adrenaline-charged comic novelist Matthue Roth. 

The CD featured work from Adam Gibson and the Aerial Maps, indie rock legend Kim Salmon, Canadian poets Ian Ferrier and Jim Christy, New Zealander Hinemoana Baker, and a young Geoff Lemon, who would later go on to edit Going Down Swinging.

Published 2008

name: Going Down Swinging #26 Limited Edition Hard Cover
description: Editors: Steve Grimwade, Lisa Greenaway Going Down Swinging’s most extraordinary print production was the extra-special hardback version of #26. Where the paperback included prints of intricate stencil art from five of Melbourne’s best street artists, these special editions included originals of the same artworks at four times the size. The variation in colouring and technique means that each book is distinct from the next. Hand-bound and individually numbered, these are collector’s items in the truest sense of the term. Only two copies remain. As the prospectus stated at the time, “This is an unprecedented opportunity to collect the work of HaHa, Vexta, Tom Civil, Miso and Ghostpatrol – artists whose works normally adorn the laneways of Melbourne, but who now, for the first time, can be collected in this unique publication.” “Only thirty copies of this hardback edition have been created. Each issue has been lovingly hand-bound by Irwin & McClaren Bookbinders in law buckram with a clear foil stamp. Each issue features five limited edition artworks – one from each artist. Each artwork is tipped in, so that it folds out effortlessly from the hardback binding.” If you wish to purchase the Limited Edition, please email us at info@goingdownswinging.org.au, rather than purchasing through the shopping cart. The special edition of Going Down Swinging #26 had only 15 copies offered for sale. The books are bound in law buckram hardcover with a foil-stamped cover motif, with hand-cut and hand-bound pages, and inserts of the original hand-made poster-size prints of the artworks and stencils featured in the issue. The paints and techniques change from work to work, so every one of the fifteen copies is unique. Published 2008 ___________________________________________________ To help us avoid fees, the best payment method is direct deposit to our bank account. Get your purchase total from the checkout page, then deposit that amount in our account via netbank or a branch deposit. name: Going Down Swinging #26 Hard Cover
description:
Only a few hardcover copies remain of GDS #26, lovingly hand-bound by Irwin & McClaren Bookbinders in law buckram with a clear foil stamp. These contain the content of the regular #26 edition, with prints of the street art section, rather than the five original artworks offered in the limited edition hardcover #26 also available on our site.

Editors: Steve Grimwade, Lisa Greenaway

With #26 began what are now known as the Greenaway years – five editions with a clear, consistent format, and an aesthetic that placed elegance first. Going Down Swinging was remade in trade paperback size, with textured cover stock, high GSM paper, uniform font and masthead, luscious cover images, and a sleeved CD held in a sliced cover-fold.

Inside the ‘Shhhh’ cover by design star Tom Civil, this issue focused on street art from Melbourne’s laneway walls. It reproduced artworks from Civil, Vexta, HaHa, Miso, and Ghostpatrol.

There was an epic desert narrative from a young Anna Krien, whose book Into the Woods would go on to win prizes at the Queensland and Victorian Premiers’ Awards; and a story from Leanne Hall, whose would win the Text Prize for her novel This is Shyness.

There was audio work from electronic music legend David Thrussell, Ian McBryde’s collaboration as The Still Company, and Citizen Tom’s new alter ego Thomas, Jack of Hearts.

It also featured the first contribution from Hawaiian writer Eric Paul Shaffer, who would go on to become a GDS regular over subsequent issues, as would Fiona Wright, who has her second publication here. Grant Caldwell and PiO keep the flag flying for the early names.

Published 2008.


  ___________________________________________________

name: Going Down Swinging - The Back Issues
description:
In the modern age of GDS, from #25 to #30, the focus was on bringing you great art and literature wrapped up in a beautiful product. The editorship of Steve Grimwade, Lisa Greenaway, Klare Lanson, Ella Holcombe, and Nathan Curnow produced large-format editions, with full-colour covers, colour artwork selections, and more.

Tracing backwards from #24, we find the grittier, punkier aesthetic of GDS through the Grimwade/alicia sometimes/Adam Ford era, with its bold artwork and innovative format. Books from #18 to #22 were matched to the size of the CDs that came with them, as they began the spoken word legacy that GDS carries on to this day. They're also a fascinating early look at some now-familiar names. 

If you're interested in more than one of these back issues, consider our Deluxe Box Set, containing all issues from #18 to #29 at a much discounted price.

(Issues before #18 are scarce, and some are unavailable, but we may be able to help - enquire direct at info@goingdownswinging.org.au)
